awd_titl_txt: Determining Grain Boundary Solute Segregation Specificity in Nanocrystalline Stability
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:  

When the grain size of a material is reduced, the strength of a material increases. Unfortunately, these small grain sizes are energetically unfavorable as compared to larger sized grains. Upon heating, the smaller grains will grow to reduce this energy difference which results in the loss of strength. In recent years, the development of specific types of alloys has shown that the lower concentration atom type, or solute, can stabilize these grains against this growth. An outcome of these observations has been various models to explain the grain size stabilization. However, these models have several fundamental scientific gaps that still remain to be solved. For example, the modeled grain boundaries are considered equivalent wherein reality grain boundaries are diverse in their structure, energy, and mobility. The lack of experimental verification of this solute specific segregation to grain boundaries has hindered further model development. This research will overcome these prior limitations by combining electron microscopy and atom probe tomography to detect solute segregation to those specific boundaries. These results will then be forward fed to atomics models that explain this diversity of behavior. This research will be integrated into various outreach activities, including a summer materials camp for secondary education teachers to introduce materials science into the middle/high school classrooms. 

Technical Abstract:

Nano-crystalline materials is an area of active research owing to their unique size dependent properties. Since interfaces (boundaries) constitute a large fraction of the entire structure, the corresponding interfacial energy from those boundaries can make these grains inherently unstable. Solute partitioning to these boundaries has been devised as a means to stabilize these grains against growth with concepts of kinetic solute drag effects and thermodynamic reduction of interfacial energy being suggested mechanisms for stabilization. To date, these models assume all the grain boundaries are isotropic and equivalent to each other; in reality grain boundaries are diverse in energy, structure, and mobility with solute partitioning being a function of that variability. Using cross-correlative precession electron diffraction and atom probe tomography, this research will elucidate the solute specificity to grain boundaries that leads to stabilization. The experimental findings will be linked to hydride Monte Carlo-Molecular Dynamics atomistic models that will elucidate the mechanisms of stabilization to specific boundary types.    In addition, real-time experimental quantification of those boundaries during annealing will be measured to ascertain mobility and kinetic contributors to stability. The collective results will bridge outstanding and fundamental knowledge gaps in revealing how thermodynamic and kinetic considerations for specific grain boundaries leads to grain size stability. This research will be seamlessly integrated to various outreach activities to strengthen the STEM disciplines including a summer materials camp for secondary education teachers to introduce materials science into middle/high school classrooms.

por.por_cntn:
Materials are often composed of a polycrystalline grain structure. When those grains are reduced to the nanometer length scale, which is 100-1000X smaller than the diameter of a human hair, the material can exhibit remarkable strength. However, when grains are this small, they tend to coarsen which results in a loss of that strength. In this research, we aimed to fundamentally understand how specific atoms in a metal alloy would segregate to the grain boundaries to prevent that grain growth. To achieve this characterization, we coupled electron microscopy with atom probe tomography. Electron microscopy enables electrons to scatter from the crystals allowing one to measure the orientation change from one grain to another, which is referred to as misorientation. Atom probe tomography allows one to identify atoms and reconstruct where they come from in the material. By comparing the misorientation to the atomic chemical detection, the research was able to characterize which atoms trend with which grain boundary mis-orientation types. Using this information, we successfully identified how specific atom types would chemically react with impurity atoms found in the material which then stabilized the grain sizes from growing. In addition, we identified how other types of atoms would separate from each other in the grain boundary in a transformation called spinodal decomposition. Those same atoms would also stabilize specific structures, called facets, in the grain boundary which was identified using a high-resolution electron microscope that directly imaged the atoms. Finally, we used this experimental information as inputs into a model, called phase field, that described how the different atoms would mix into the grain boundaries and how those grains would then grow.  The phase field model represented the grain boundaries as a lower density region. Through this modeling, we captured how the atoms evolved under various time and temperatures that explain the mechanisms of nanocrystalline grain stability.

The combined outcomes of these findings enabled a scientific understanding on how to select specific atom types that can retain the smaller grain sizes, hence strength, even when the metal is heated and grain growth could be promoted. How those specific atom types in those grain boundaries alters the chemical and crystallographic structure was identified providing information in understanding in how to engineer grain boundaries themselves. This collectively allows the information required to make materials with improved physical properties. These findings were disseminated through peer-review publications and conference presentations to the scientific community. 

The ability to characterize grains at these atomic length sizes was developed under this program and is now being promoted to others that can do similar characterization correlations in their research, expanding the impact of this research outside the specific metals studied.

Other broader impacts include mentoring a rising generation of STEM students. The two graduate students that have received support through this program are now employed in the US national aerospace and defense industry. Other activities include engaging middle and high school teachers in a one-week camp that allows them to learn about materials and how to incorporate that information with low-cost hands-on demos that students can do in physics, chemistry, and physical science classes.
